True, lawyers change their opinions and legal attitudes have changed over the years. Some years ago those who considered the matter may have believed that the greater the number of small unions the better. We now know that there is a better chance of individual members having a better union and better facilities within that union if they are members of a union which can employ specialist staffs and meet Government, employers or representative bodies on a footing of equality.

We know that trade unions no longer must confine their activities to mere wage negotiations. Increasingly unions must be able to understand the problems of the economy at large and, in order to do that, they must be able to employ staff, international staff, specialist economic staff, the kind of staff competent to translate their members' aspirations into action. We met unions at the beginning of the autumn months and we will be meeting them increasingly in the months ahead and it certainly serves the national interest when, meeting these unions, we are faced with representatives and staff backed by adequate service in their head offices. Where the law previously impeded unions coming together this legislation removes that obstacle. That is a big advance and it should be a solid encouragement to unions to come together. The last legislation in this area was sometime around 1970.

Earlier I told Deputy Moore that we cannot force people in free association to come together. This is on a piece with all legislation attempted in the area of industrial relations. Legislation must facilitate and encourage. It cannot coerce because that would be both undesirable and unsucessful, as we know from the experience of those who attempted that course elsewhere. Deputy Dowling is at one with me in his desire to see unions come together. He is at one with me in agreeing with the provisions of this legislation. He agrees there must be an executive authority within Ireland to govern the affairs of Irish unions. In this legislation we are putting an end to the situation in which Irish unions were controlled from outside. This is a first step in a very complicated area. Since Deputy Dowling is in agreement with the many changes involved in this legislation I would ask him to withdraw this amendment because I believe its acceptance would take us back to a state of affairs we are now intent on leaving, that state of affairs in which the law was itself an actual impediment to the coming together of unions, a costly situation and a complicated area of warring interpretations as to the legal rights and wrongs of unions coming together.

In section 3 we discharge adequately our duty to ensure members will take part in a fair ballot. We provide for the principle of majority decision. If we can form the Government of the country by a majority vote surely we should accept the same principle when it is a question of unions coming together. It smacks of paternalism to suggest that when it is a question of an association of workers coming together the State should step in and suggest a certain percentage majority before a verdict may be recorded as just and reasonable. I know that is far from Deputy Dowling's mind. It is the thinking of a period now past and the fact that it is past is something we should welcome.

Majority vote is a reliable indication of the validity of any decision. Taken in conjunction with section 3 it ensures the union must take all reasonable steps to ensure that not less than seven days before the voting all those entitled to vote must be in full possession of the facts. The voter must be given all the relevant information to enable the voter to form a reasonable judgement and, if the union does not set out all the terms of the instrument, it must tell the voter clearly where copies of the instrument may be inspected. If all these provisions in section 3 are not complied with there is an appeal to the registrar. The union executive committee will know that there is such an appeal.

Section 3 transforms every union member into a custodian of justice and fairness. Deputy Dowling knows the area of industrial relations. He knows it is not an area susceptible of sweeping gestures. We cannot coerce solutions. It is an area in which we must persuade and argue and take modest steps along the road to improving things. This legislation provides that the executive must reside in Ireland and it is hoped that this will result in nudging those members of unions based outside this country in the direction of taking control of their own affairs. Deputy Dowling is of the same mind as I am on many of these things. I would appreciate his support in this. His amendment would mean a lapse back into a past to which none of us wish to return. We are clearing away now certain legal impediments. Majority rule is something from which we should not depart.

Speaker.P: I agree with most of what the Minister has said. As a matter of fact I had already said much of what he has stated. He made one point in relation to the formation of Government by majority vote. There is provision in legislation for postal votes. It is clearly written into legislation in relation to parliamentary elections——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: It is here also. I have told the Deputy that.

——and in relation to local elections. It is more specific than it is here. It specifies the manner in which postal votes can be obtained. There is a special register for postal votes for the Garda, for the Army and for other people. There is a difference between this legislation and the legislation dealing with a parliamentary election.

The Minister should be a little more reasonable on the point we have made asking him to be specific about the postal vote. As a layman I would ask him to write into the Bill a section that can be clearly understood by trade unionists who have not got a lawyer at their disposal all the time to interpret the Bill and who would like to read the Bill and see that they have this concession. The Minister feels it is written into the Bill and I feel it is not. If it is, it should be more specific and it should be clear to union members. Section 3 (1) (a) provides that every member of the union shall be entitled to vote on the resolution. He is entitled to vote, but that is as far as it goes.
That is the first heading I mentioned. Go on to the next one.

Section 3 (1) (b) provides that every member of the union shall be allowed to vote without interference or constraint and, so far as is reasonably possible, shall be given a fair opportunity of voting. That is fair enough. I agree with that. The next one is the important one. Section 3 (1) (c) provides that the method of voting shall consist of the marking of a voting paper by the person voting.
That precludes the showing of hands type of voting.
The Minister indicated earlier that he would amend this to deal with the secret ballot. I think he said he will have that written into section 3.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: That is true.
To me a secret ballot——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: I think this is adequately covered in paragraph (c). I have no doubt about it.

The interpretation of a secret ballot is a group of people going to a union meeting and instead of putting up their hands voting on a paper. That does not give the person the right to vote by post and that is the important issue.

It does because paragraph (b) is there. How can you construe it otherwise? If a person is down in Killorglin when the voting is taking place in Dublin he must be given a postal vote. Otherwise paragraph (b) is not complied with.

If a person has the right to vote by post there must be provision for his obtaining a ballot paper by post. That provision is not here. It is not indicated to me that there is provision for a person to vote by post. We have consistently made the point that we want the collective wisdom of the union to be effective in any decision arrived at. If it is, then a simple majority will suffice.

The Minister said he will provide in the section for the question of a secret ballot. If the secret ballot is embodied in the subsection it refers only to a meeting where a show of hands would take place as against a secret ballot. That indicates to me that if a person on Fastnet Rock or down in Galway put up his hand, his vote could be recorded if this section were not in the Bill. That is not enough. His vote must be recorded in writing and he should have that opportunity which, to my mind, is not given to him in the Bill.
It says: “...so far as is reasonably possible, shall be given a fair opportunity of voting.” How can it be a fair opportunity of voting unless he has the postal ballot?

It is not unreasonable to ask that the matter should be clarified to a degree to which I could understand it. I may be very dull but I regard myself as a normal individual. I am not a lawyer. I could well understand that a lawyer would read that into the section.

If you wanted to go into particularities like that you would possibly have to preclude a pencil as against a biro or a piece of chalk and you might endanger the overall legislation. That is one of the dangers. They did this in America with legislation and got themselves into trouble. Let us not make the same mistake.

In order to ensure that people could vote by post the Minister for Local Government had to bring in special legislation. People had the same right to vote under the legislation before that, and every attempt was made to ensure that they could vote without interference or constraint.
In a parliamentary election you have to vote in a certain place and in a certain ballot box. That is different from what is here.
I think Members will agree that we have deliberated on this amendment for some considerable time. May I now ask how stands the amendment?

The Minister should give an assurance that he will use some phraseology that will be understandable to the normal person rather than to lawyers only. I was a member of a union that merged and the funds of that union were eaten up by lawyers. I do not want that to happen again. I have every respect for the viewpoint of a lawyer and it is necessary that we should get the legal viewpoint when compiling legislation. It would not take very much for the Minister to say yes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: I say sincerely that the Deputy may be better than my advisers and me at putting it into the kind of language he desires. We have made the language as understandable as possible to allow for as many contingencies as possible. If the Deputy sets down his attempt at simple language in this section for Report Stage I will have a look at it. I cannot accept this amendment which would seriously impair the effectiveness of what I have in mind. When it came to the actual decision by the union going into a merger or an amalgamation I wanted to get away from the requirement of this kind of majority or that kind of majority and, instead, to accept fully the validity of the majority decision with the inbuilt guarantee that it was a decision based on the knowledge and consent of the members involved. If the Deputy elaborates on section 3 for Report Stage I will look at it favourably. I have already accepted any points which I felt legitimately could be added without impairing the spirit or the content of the legislation.
Will the Minister reword paragraph (c) in relation to the secret ballot?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: I have undertaken to do that.
I know that, but we would want to see the phraseology.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: I undertake to do that for Report Stage and I will also consider——
Could we have it at an early stage so that we can consider it?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: We will send the Deputy a copy fully seven days before Report Stage.
Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.
Section 5 agreed to.
Progress reported; Committee to sit again.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Discussions with French Prime Minister.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lynch Mr. J. Lynch
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if he will make a comprehensive statement on his recent discussions with the French Prime Minister with particular reference to whether any agreement or proposal was made or undertaking given in relation to the regional fund of the European Economic Community.

It would not be in accordance with normal practice to reveal details of my discussions with the French Prime Minister. As the Deputy will appreciate, much of the value of such meetings depends on their confidentiality.

However, I may say that we discussed the following subjects—preparations for a possible conference of heads of Government of the member States of the European Community and the proposals for regular meetings of this kind; the regional policy and proposed regional fund of the Community; energy; oil and natural gas; agriculture, including the common agricultural policy of the EEC and certain bilateral problems in relation to Irish exports of sheep and lamb; the improvement of trade and other economic relations between Ireland and France; the furtherance of cultural and educational relations and of scientific co-operation between the two countries; the transfer of the Presidency in the context of the European Community from France to Ireland as from 1st January, 1975; Northern Ireland; Aer Lingus' wish to transfer its operations at Paris from Le Bourget to Orly Airport, and the delimitation of the continental shelf for the purposes of exploration for and exploitation of natural resources.

MainHeading.P: The proposed regional fund is a matter of concern to every member State of the EEC. I can say, without any breach of confidentiality, that Monsieur Chirac stated his conviction that the fund was in line with the spirit and philosophy of the Community and that it should be set up quickly. He also expressed the view, however, that the establishment of a large regional fund which would be invested generally throughout the Community was not consistent with the fight against inflation which France considered to be the priority problem of the moment. Monsieur Chirac suggested for consideration, that as a compromise, and as an interim stage to a regional fund proper, open to all member States, a smaller temporary fund should be established, for a period of one, two or three years until certain criteria on, say, rates of inflation had been met— the fund to be invested only in Italy and Ireland.

I explained the Government's position on a regional fund, including our reservations on the proposed conference of heads of Government. I indicated that we had noted his suggestion for the fund with considerable interest. The matter is the subject of continuing discussions.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lynch Mr. J. Lynch
Speaker.P: I appreciate the suggestion of the Taoiseach that these talks, if they are to be of any value, must remain confidential. Is he aware that my purpose in tabling this question was, in fact, related to M. Chirac's announcement during the course of an interview about this limited regional fund? Would the Taoiseach indicate if there was any question of an undertaking being given by him or through his appropriate Minister, that he supports the establishment of such a limited fund?

This matter is the subject of continuing discussions. I understand a variation of the proposal was made on Monday to the extent that the amount of the fund would be unspecified. Included in that unspecified fund, the percentage which Ireland would draw was similar to that referred to earlier. All these proposals are to be again discussed on Monday next. That is the situation at the moment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lynch Mr. J. Lynch
Speaker.P: Will the Taoiseach be able to indicate, arising out of the meeting of Foreign Ministers earlier this week if the prospect of holding a summit conference next month appeared any brighter?
Again, this will come up for discussion on Monday. The position is that Italy and Ireland both reserve their positions on this and a lot depends on what happens on Monday.
Is the Taoiseach hopeful that a regional fund will be operational early next year?

As I said, it all depends on the discussions next week and probably subsequent discussions if there is a meeting of heads of Government. There is, I think I am correct in saying, some support for the idea of an interim regional fund but it depends not only on France and Ireland and Britain and Italy as two other interested countries but also very much on the German attitude.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Fodder Stocks.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if he will instruct county committees of agriculture to request their advisers to take a stock census which will establish the feed and fodder position of each farm in their areas.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. Clinton) Mark A. Clinton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. Clinton)
Speaker.P: If I were to ask the advisory officers to make a full and complete survey of every farm, they would have no time whatsoever to carry out their normal work.

Would the Minister not think it would have been time well spent from other duties to assess this? Does he not realise that many farmers in the planning situation sold their cattle at £4 and £5 per cwt? Had they known of the availability of feed and had a stock census been taken at harvest time, this might not have been the case.

Most people know the number of livestock in the country. They are also aware that there is insufficient fodder, generally speaking. This is not a new phenomenon incidentally. I never remember a year when farmers had enough fodder for the entire winter. It is not a practical proposition to suggest that within the time available this survey would be completed by the 375 advisers in the field. We have in excess of seven million cattle and 160,000 farmers. This is not a possibility.
At the present time when there is less work for inspectors in grass seed, oats and so forth, could they not have been employed to secure that information?
If the Deputy is suggesting that there are people working for the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries who are half idle at the moment, I would not accept that suggestion.

I am not suggesting that. What I am asking is if these men could not have been taken from that work for two or three months to compile this information. If the farmers had known that feed would have been available, they would not have brought their cattle to the market and sold them——
The Deputy is entering into the realm of a debate.
——for a fraction of their cost when they were dropped calves.
What the Deputy is suggesting is being done in a general way. The advisers know which farmers in their areas are in serious trouble.
Have the Department any way of bringing that information to the farmers?
I have given the Deputy a lot of latitude. We must make progress.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if he will give an up-to-date account of the extent and availability of fodder for cattle during the coming six months.

In some parts of the country, mainly western areas, supplies of fodder are likely to be tight this winter. In view of this I have arranged for the introduction of special measures to help the smaller farmers concerned. These comprise loans at reduced interest and a feed voucher scheme under which farmers are assisted to buy grain and concerntrates, of which adequate supplies are available. Disposal of cattle through slaughterings at meat factories and through exports on the hoof have been at record levels for some time past and this reduction of stocks will also help to reduce fodder difficulties.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: On what is the Minister basing his information with regard to the scarcity of fodder? This also applies to Question No. 2.
Some considerable time ago I asked the advisory services to make a general assessment of the situation. Their advice is continually coming to my Department.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Is the Minister satisfied that the grants and the loans at special interest rates are sufficient to enable those with young stock, particularly those in the west and south-west, to buy fodder for their animals? Is the Minister aware that there is an extreme scarcity of fodder?

I am satisfied they represent a substantial help to people who are in difficulty about fodder. While the maximum amount issued in the first instance is assistance to buy a ton of fodder—£30 of a subsidy on a ton of fodder—I am hoping that the fund will be large enough to continue this for the period the people need it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Can the Minister state the extent of the export of fodder in recent weeks? We have had a large traffic in cross-Border activities in this regard and I should like to know what action the Minister, or any other Minister, proposes to take to prevent this happening.

As I explained to the House, there is no action open to me. There is free movement of grain throughout the Community and there is no action I can take to prevent this. There is no scarcity of grain. If we were to do what the Deputy is suggesting we could not import the large amount of grain we require for our own purposes.
Deputy Callanan.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Would the Minister agree that there has been a lot of exporting of grain across the Border?
The Chair has called another Deputy and must be obeyed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Deputy Callanan, I am sure, will give way to me to ask my supplementary.
It is all right if the Deputy defers but the Chair must not be ignored. Will Deputy Callanan give way?
I suppose I have to.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: I am thankful to the Chair who is so kind, generous and thoughtful.
The Deputy should have obeyed the Chair in the first instance when he heard his colleague called.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Would the Minister agree that the situation would be relieved if greater efforts were made to find markets abroad in third countries for our young cattle?
I emphatically deny and contradict that. The maximum effort has been made to find markets abroad.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: It is hyprocrisy on the Minister's part to say that when he knows the opposite to be true.

Is the Minister aware that because the price of grain is increasing so rapidly there is a danger that the £30 per ton subsidy will be eaten up? The price of grain has already increased because everybody is availing of the subsidy.
I can do nothing about the movement of grain. Of course, there has been some movement up in price but it has not been a very rapid one.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: The Minister is giving farmers money to compete with each other to borrow money but he will not put a price control on feedingstuffs.
I am talking about the grain at home.
I have no power to put on any controls.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: The Government have.
The Government have not in this instance.
Can the Minister say what the position is about hay and straw exports?
Within the Community I can do nothing about their export.
Can the Minister not check with the millers and compounders and keep some control on them because it is these people who are exporting?
They are exporting legally.
The Chair is calling the next question.
Is the Minister aware that there has been an increase of between £3 and £4 per ton in the price of grain in the last week?
asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if cattle feed vouchers will be issued to farmers in the State; and whether the amount of money allocated will be sufficient to meet the demand.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries the number of applications received to date for financial aid either in grant or loan form to help keep cattle during the winter; and the total amounts of money already disbursed.
With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle I propose to take Questions Nos. 4 and 5 together.

MainHeading.P: As I announced on the 8th November, the meat exporters, at my request, agreed in mid-October to contribute 1p per 1b, up to the end of December, on all beef sold into intervention, the proceeds to be used to assist farmers in difficulty to feed young stock over the winter. Feed vouchers financed under this arrangement have been made available by the Irish Fresh Meat Exporters Society and these are currently being distributed through the local services of my Department and the county committees of agriculture.

By the end of last week some 21,000 applications for vouchers had been received. These are being examined as a matter of urgency and the distribution of vouchers, which applicants will use in part-payment for feed, has now commenced.

It is not possible at this stage to indicate the extent of the likely demand. The amount of money available will, of course, depend on the quantities of beef sold into intervention up to the end of the year.

With regard to the new subsidised loan scheme which I also announced on 8th November, the number of applications received to date is 210. Sixteen loans, totalling £5,650, have been granted by the ACC.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Can the Minister say if all genuine applications for financial aid will be met?
All applications that come within the requirements as advertised will be met.

Does the Minister not agree that because of the big number of applicants for this subsidy the price will increase? While there is no control on the export of fodder surely the Minister has control over the home millers?
The price of feeding-stuffs has been decontrolled. This was done because everybody in the business felt it was the best way to keep prices down.
It was not the feeling of everybody concerned.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Calf Market.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries the steps being taken by him to provide a market for calves next spring.

As a result of the decision of the Council of Ministers in October to change the representative rate for the Irish pound the monetary compensatory amount charges on exports of calves were substantially reduced. This has already resulted in an increase in exports to Italy and third countries.

At my request also, the EEC Commission last week agreed to propose restitutions for the export to third countries of calves and other cattle which do not qualify for the slaughter premium. These restitutions should further stimulate the export of calves and help the market situation here, if they are agreed.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Factory Cattle Acceptance.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if he is aware that meat factories will not accept cattle which have reacted to the brucellosis or tuberculosis tests until March, 1975; and if his Department will make arrangements with the meat factories to have such cattle accepted as a matter of priority.
I am not so aware. There is no undue delay in the acceptance at meat factories of reactors taken up under my Department's brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication schemes.

MainHeading.P: The Deputy may, however, have in mind the pre-intensive brucellosis scheme under which the disposal of reactors to meat factories is a matter for private arrangement by the herd-owner. I am aware, and am concerned, that there are delays on the part of meat factories in accepting these reactor cows due no doubt to the large numbers of cattle being offered to them at present. The matter is essentially one for the proprietors of the meat factories to decide as to the acceptance or otherwise of animals offered to them for slaughter. I would suggest that herdowners might enlist the support of their farming organisations in prevailing on meat factories to take up, as quickly as possible, reactors disclosed at tests carried out under the pre-intensive scheme.

Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that where there are TB reactors very often his officials do not arrive for four or five weeks after being notified? I can give several instances of that. Does the Minister think it right for the meat factories to refuse those cattle in the not-too-intensive areas? I should like the Minister to make it incumbent on the meat factories to take such animals in immediately they are notified.

My information is that there is not undue delay in relation to TB reactors because they are contracted for. I had the processors in some months ago concerning this matter and the position was brought up-to-date. For that reason I cannot understand the allegation made by the Deputy, but if he has any particular instances of this I would be glad to have details.

What advice would the Minister give to a farmer whose cattle have gone down on the ring test and whose cards have been taken up? On that account, he is precluded from selling them on the open market and there is a local law in some of the meat factories that they will not accept cattle that will not kill out at a weight greater than 500 lbs. What advice would the Minister offer a farmer in that case?

There is no law in relation to the acceptance of cattle under 500 lbs. The demand for cows killing out under 500 lbs. is very poor. Consequently, the factories are not anxious to take them. I know there is a special difficulty with regard to these but there is no way in which I can compel factories to take them.

Does the Minister not now consider that the Government scheme, which was laudable in its intention, is not operating properly; that it was never considered that it should be such a hardship on farmers and that the Minister should take some action in this matter?
To which scheme is the Deputy referring?
The test scheme and the disposal of cattle that react to it. Is it not the Minister's duty to see that they are removed?

Where the Department schemes are operating—apart from the pre-intensive scheme—it is all done on a contractual arrangement and there is no undue delay. I am insisting that there is not. If any Deputy knows of any person or persons who have been held up unduly, I shall be very glad to receive the name or names involved.
Would the Minister not agree that the pre-intensive scheme should get the same treatment as the compulsory one?
It is a matter there for the individual to make his own arrangements. Deputies should be reasonable about this.
Deputy Crinion, a final supplementary.
Never in the history of the country did the processing firms put through anything like the same number of stock they are putting through at present. It is simply a question of capacity.

Farms locked up as a result of having had reactors to brucellosis and tuberculosis are confined to selling to the factory. In a large number of cases the cattle cannot be got into a factory. In those cases would the Minister use his good offices to try to get cattle placed in some factory?
I do not accept what the Deputy says. My information is that there is no undue delay where the Department are doing this testing.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Mare Nomination Tickets.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if he intends to increase the charge in respect of mare nomination tickets to bring them into line with present day costs.
I presume the Deputy is referring to the value of a mare nomination which I do not intend to increase.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Cold Storage Facilities.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries the plans, if any, he has to encourage the building of greater cold storage facilities during the coming year; and if he will encourage outside firms to set up cold storage facilities which could be rented to Irish manufacturers.

While the IDA policy in grant aiding cold stores is to consider applications only where the storage proposal forms part of a manufacturing application, the authority has agreed at my request that as an exceptional measure grants will be given for the provision by existing firms of an additional one million cubic feet of cold storage space. This extra space will ease pressure on cold storage facilities during the coming year.
How much of that one million cubic feet does the Minister expect will be built during the coming year?
My information is that the total has already been taken up.
Are these people outside the manufacturing end? Will factories themselves qualify for such grants for providing the equipment?
In the circumstances I have described it was not necessary to have a processing factory to qualify.
Some of them have applied to the Minister.
I think the total capacity agreed has been taken up, the million cubic feet.
It is not the Minister's intention to grant assistance to factory owners in the provision of this cold storage?
No, any grant aid that emanates comes from the IDA. If there is a manufacturing process, the IDA will consider it in the normal way.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Ergot Poisoning.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if there has been an unusual increase in the incidence of ergot poisoning in cattle this year; and, if so, if he has any plans to counter it.

There has been an unusual increase this year in the incidence of ergot poisoning in cattle. As the factors involved in ergot poisoning are many and complex, my Department's veterinary research laboratories are giving all possible advice and assistance to farmers and their veterinary surgeons where cases are brought to notice. For the coming year my Department will arrange suitable publicity with a view to helping farmers to identify this dangerous fungus which develops in seed heads and to protect their stock against it.

I asked the Minister if he had any plans to counter the increase in poisoning this year. The Minister has indicated that the veterinary people propose taking specific steps next year. I want to find out from the Minister whether there is anything he can do to help farmers whose cattle have become affected by this poisoning this year because there is no way out for them. Would the Minister consider, in any shape or form, the possibility of having those cattle taken on to some departmental line in view of the fact that factories will not accept cattle affected or even cattle that might be in the early stages of suffering from this ergot poisoning?

As the Deputy knows, this disease is not peculiar to this country. It is not covered in other countries by any special assistance. The feeling in the Department is that the maximum that can be done is to publicise the ways and means of avoiding it. That is, if one is cutting silage and hay, it should be cut before the seed head stage because it is in the seed head that the fungus develops. Beyond that, not an awful lot can be done because there is no treatment for the disease.

Arising from a similar question some time ago, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister said that those farmers could apply to the ACC for money to restock. The problem in this regard is restocking, using the silage already creating the poison and putting cattle out on the land affected. Could the Minister not visualise any way in which his Department could help, or make arrangements to help, by providing some type of alternative feeding or accommodation for affected herds and the farmers owning them?
Fortunately these cases are not very numerous but, where they hit, they hit very hard. The means of avoiding it are within the competence of the farmer himself.
That is for next year.
Unfortunately, it hits and hits very suddenly. The farmer does not get an opportunity of combating it if he has not had it before.
The Minister said that the numbers are not numerous but he must agree that the incidence is becoming more common?
They have been more numerous this year: that is agreed.
Would the Minister consider giving special assistance in such cases because he must realise that farmers who have stock affected this year are losing a fortune?

Yes, there is a great difficulty here. If one singles out one disease of this kind and provides special assistance, there will be demands all over the place for assistance in respect of all the diseases causing mortality.

Is it not a fact that ergot poisoning occurs only in years of very heavy rainfall, particularly at the latter end of the year? The Minister mentioned the fact that it was within the competence of farmers to combat it. I say to the Minister——
A question, Deputy, please.
——that his Department never advertised or told farmers——
A question please.
In such circumstances surely the Minister should offer some compensation to the farmers concerned because rarely does it happen?
I am afraid the Deputy is making a speech rather than asking a question.
The Department have gone to a considerable amount of trouble to diagnose the disease and at least to tell the farmer what was wrong with his cattle and how it could be avoided in the future.
That is not much good.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Paraquat Poisoning.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Belton Mr. L. Belton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if, in view of the alarming number of deaths from paraquat poisoning, he will ban the use of paraquat and also of gramoxone which contains a high percentage of paraquat.

My Department is at present in touch with the Department of Health and the manufacturers about the introduction of further controls and safeguards in connection with the sale and distribution of paraquat as well as the issue of further warnings concerning the dangers associated with its use. Pending the outcome of these contacts, I do not propose to ban the distribution of the preparation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Belton Mr. L. Belton
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that in the last four years there have been 44 deaths from the use of paraquat? Even if he were satisfied that sufficient restrictions had been imposed on the sale of it, is he aware that many purchasers insist on dispensing it into smaller containers? Is he aware also that the county physician for Monaghan stated recently that he was able to purchase a container of paraquat without signing the register and that there was also within easy reach 12 bottles which could be stolen by the most amateur thief? Furthermore, is the Minister aware that the coroner at an inquest in South Galway stated that the country would be much better off without this product? Does he not regard this as sufficient reason for banning the sale of it?

The Deputy is probably aware that out of the 44 deaths referred to the information I have at least indicates that no more than seven of these were due to accidental poisoning, mainly suicidal poisonings. Of course it is not the only poison that is on the market, but it is readily to hand. Then there is also the decanting of it, or the putting of it into smaller bottles, which is completely illegal. The Department of Health have made that clear.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Belton Mr. L. Belton
Speaker.P: In other words, the Minister cannot control it?

I can see there is an extreme difficulty but at the same time it is a very valuable weedkiller and foliage killer. Apparently there are a number of substances being tested at the moment that may replace it, but it is not the only poison that is freely available to people. I do not know why paraquat seems to be the one that has caused so much trouble.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Belton Mr. L. Belton
Speaker.P: Could the Minister say if there is any result of the test that was supposed to be carried out on human guinea pigs in north County Dublin by ICI with regard to the effect the inhaling of paraquat would have on human beings? Is there any result of that test?
Human guinea pigs?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Belton Mr. L. Belton
Speaker.P: Yes. It was announced in the Press.
I am not aware of the experiment the Deputy is referring to.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Belton Mr. L. Belton
Speaker.P: The Minister does not know of any result of these tests?
I am not aware of the experiment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Belton Mr. L. Belton
Speaker.P: It was announced in the Press.
Can the Minister assure the House that the amounts of gramoxone that are on sale at the moment contain this foul-smelling substance as mentioned by the Minister?
My information is they do.
All of them carry it?
All of them are supposed to contain it. I cannot be certain that there are not quantities left over on farms or elsewhere that do not contain it.
Could the Minister take some action in this regard and see to it that whatever quantity of the old stock is lying around is disposed of because this is what causes the trouble.
Again, the Deputy knows the difficulty in seeking this out and finding the people who have it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Belton Mr. L. Belton
Speaker.P: Is the Minister satisfied that this paraquat cannot be purchased without somebody signing the register?
That is the law. It is being purchased illegally if it is purchased otherwise.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Belton Mr. L. Belton
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware of the statement of the Monaghan county physician that he could purchase it without being asked to sign for it?
I cannot answer the Deputy's supplementary question.

Did the Minister's Department take any action following a disclosure in this House a month ago that gramoxone without this foul smelling additive was on sale? Did his Department take any action to ensure that it would be taken off the market?
I cannot answer that supplementary question.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Sugar Beet Price.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries when it is expected that an agreed price for next year's sugar beet crop will be announced.

The fixing of a price for sugar beet of the 1975 crop is a matter for negotiation between Comhlucht Siúicre Éireann Teo. and representatives of the growers. I understand that negotiations are at present in progress but it is not possible to say when they are likely to be concluded.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Disadvantaged Area Scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries the extent of his consultations with the county committees of agriculture in the preparation of submissions to the EEC with regard to the establishment of the disadvantaged areas scheme.

The proposed directive on disadvantaged areas lays down very specific criteria for the selection of areas to come within the scope of the measure. These include the nature and quality of the land, various economic indices and population criteria. Adequate information on these factors was available to my Department from published data and other sources and it was not therefore necessary to enter into consultations with county committees of agriculture or other local organisations.

In view of the rumours that some of the western areas—for instance, County Donegal —are about to be partitioned by the proposals put forward under Directive 161 by the Minister and the Government, will the Minister deny that this is so? If it is so, would it not be advisable to consult members of local agricultural committees on the matter before this sort of thing is done?

I was quite surprised to find that the people in the Commission knew as much about these areas as we knew about them. They knew that in parts of Donegal there are areas as good as any part of County Meath or any part of the Golden Vale.
County Meath is much nearer to Dublin than Donegal.
That is so but you cannot describe certain areas in the Lagan valley that I know of as disadvantaged areas by any stretch of the imagination.

Distance from markets, cost of transport both ways, are some of the criteria mentioned in Directive 161. If Donegal is to be partitioned by the Minister's proposals then he is not adhering to the criteria of Directive 161.

All I can say to the Deputy is that I was anxious to get the maximum area of the country accepted, but the Commission would not under any circumstances accept the 12 blanket counties that were normally used.
Why should they accept it when the Minister put in a different proposal?
I only put it in because, if I did not put it in, we would never have a proposal.
The Minister did not follow the criteria of the Directive.
I followed the criteria exactly. I could not be more scrupulous in following them.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Would the Minister state, because of the grave unrest that exists as a result of people being ignorant of submissions made by him to the EEC in connection with this scheme, that it is now time that all information with regard to the areas included in the Minister's proposals be made known to the public?

I will let the public know exactly the areas we eventually submitted under pressure. We would have had a scheme much earlier if I had been prepared to agree with the Commission that a very restricted area met with the criteria. I have nothing at all to hide in this. I will make available the information the Deputy is looking for anytime he puts down a question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: If, as the Minister says, he has nothing whatever to hide in this regard, I should like to remind him that a very short time ago I had a specific question to him asking him to outline the areas he proposed to submit to the EEC in regard to this scheme? I should like to jog the Minister's memory on that particular one and I should like him to say now that he will make available to Deputies this week a copy of submissions made by him on behalf of the people of Ireland in relation to this scheme?
If the Deputy puts down a question about this I will answer it, but he has not such a question on the Order Paper.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Will the Minister make available the information he promised he would, or does he want to go back on it?
I never go back on anything I say.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: The Minister has before.
If the Minister has not put forward proposals which embody the areas which he would desire to see designated——
I put them forward and got them shot down.

They were shot down on the conditions of Directive 161. In the case of the other directives the Government added finance from central funds. Is it not possible for the Minister, despite what Brussels say, to do as was done in the case of Directives 159 and 160, where the Exchequer will add to the moneys provided by the EEC so that the wishes of the Minister in relation to the small farmers in the unfavoured areas could be met? Will the Minister do this?
I hope any area that is seriously disadvantaged will be accepted. That is all that will be admitted.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that I had a question on the Order Paper about four weeks ago asking specifically that the areas to be incorporated in the scheme would be publicised by the Minister? The question was answered by his Parliamentary Secretary who refused to give the information.
I could not say what would be incorporated in the scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Can the Minister tell us what the submissions are? I asked for the submissions only.
I will give the Deputy that information if he puts down a specific question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: I cannot put down a question because I would not be allowed by the Chair.
I cannot give the information before it is submitted——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: I will not be able to put down a question for five months or so because of the rules of the House.
——and unless the circumstances have changed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: If the Minister has nothing to hide he will make the information available to Members of the House.
I am suggesting that the circumstances have changed. We now have submitted the areas. At that time we had not.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: They were submitted then by about four days.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Farm Modernisation Scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries the number of applicants under the farm modernisation scheme who will be reclassified as small or transitional farmers from the development class of farmers as a result of the serious drop in farm incomes at present.

The question of re-classifying farmers already in the development category does not arise. Such farmers have been assessed by reference to their ability to achieve the comparable income on completion of a development plan of up to six years. Plans are based on constant prices and costs and are not, therefore, affected by year to year changes.

If the scheme under this directive favours a certain type of farmer and does not help the small farmer, is there anything to prevent the Department making development grants, not necessarily EEC grants, available to small farmers?

If there was an unlimited purse and if we got the permission of the EEC, which we have to get for any additional assistance, of course we could dish it out to people all over the place, and nobody would like doing that better than I would.
I resent the implication about dishing out money to small farmers.

I am sure the Minister saw the television programme the other night where a man with 420 acres was mentioned. The adviser was asked which category he would go into. This man had 60 calves this year, 30 cows and 100 sheep and the adviser said he might be classified as a development farmer. If that is the case, will the Minister not agree that that type of scheme is useless? It appeared on television that this man might be a potential development farmer. People in my area looking at that were ready to give up the ghost.
The Deputy will appreciate I cannot discuss an individual case.
I am not asking the Minister to do that. This is the general trend in the matter of developing farmers. To my mind the scheme will have to be changed.

The type of farming carried on involves the quality of the land, the capacity of the farm itself and many other things. There is the question of whether a man is capable of reaching the comparable target of £1,800.

Would the Minister try to get us a percentage? Very few classifications have been done and is the Minister aware that the reason for that is that the advisers have been waiting for different trends in prices?
I am very surprised to hear that advisers should be thinking on those lines because of the substance of the reply I have just given. This is not based on prices at a time when prices are very low.
Could an average not be struck? Speculation is very dangerous.
Is the Minister satisfied with the rate of progress being made in the categorising of farmers?
Yes, in view of the period during which the scheme has been operating.
Is it not a fact that new directives are being sent by the Department to the county committees of agriculture every couple of weeks?

That is not so. There is constant discussion on problems arising with the advisory services whose job it is to make assessments. Any scheme that was ever introduced has shown up certain problems as time went on. It is my intention to bring these back to the EEC when we have had some sort of experience of the schemes working over a period and when we can say: “This is what is happening; these are the difficulties.”

The Minister has said there has been no delay in so far as giving a man the go ahead is concerned—if he wants to build a hayshed or do something else. But when will he be categorised? That is the point I am getting at. Ninety per cent of the instructors' time is spent going around telling the farmers they can go ahead.
It is the responsibility of the CAOs to tell them which category they are in.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Can the Minister say that because of the serious drop in farm incomes numerous farmers who would be classified in the development class are not now being reclassed into the small farmer or the transitional grades?

I have tried to explain to the Deputy that this has no effect at all on the assessment of farmers as to which category they come into. It is assessed on constant prices, normal prices, not just on abnormal prices that are there for a temporary period.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - County Donegal Pier.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if he will ensure that the electrically operated crane at Portaleen pier, County Donegal will be installed as a matter of urgency.

Speaker.hpid: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. P. Murphy) Michael Pat Murphy
Speaker.NameTxt: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. Mr. P. Murphy)
Speaker.P: The Office of Public Works have assured me that as soon as the machinery necessary for the electrical operation of this crane is delivered, that office will have it installed as a matter of urgency. Difficulty has been experienced in obtaining the machinery in question but it is now expected that it will be delivered by the end of December next.
Can the Parliamentary Secretary say if the machinery has been ordered?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: Have a little patience and you will be getting your crane at Portaleen pier in December. It is only a month.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Waterkeepers Dismissals.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries the reasons why the waterkeepers of the Board of Conservators No. 12 District were dismissed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: I assume the Deputy is referring to three members of the protection staff of No. 12 district who received dismissal notices from the board on 3rd October last. I am informed by the board that the men were dismissed due to repeated failures to carry out the instructions of the board and their inspector. The board are fully empowered under the Fisheries acts to terminate the employment of any of their officers.
Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware these men were dismissed because of their inability to act against organised fish-ins?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: They were dismissed because of their inability to carry out their duties, according to the board, or alternatively because of their unwillingness to do so. From the information supplied to the Department, the dismissals were justified. I do not know if it is wise on the Deputy's part to ask for detailed particulars of the reasons for the dismissals of particular individuals. If he does so I will answer him.
The Parliamentary Secretary has not given any answers to questions I have asked him.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: The three men were warned over a considerable period of time.
When the “fish-ins” were in progress they were unable to act.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: Because of their inability or unwillingness to carry out their duties the board had no alternative but to dispense with their services.
Because of their inability to act?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: They were dismissed because they were incapable.
Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that one of the reasons, if not the main one, for the dismissal of the three men is because they seized nets belonging to a member of the board?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: That is completely wrong, according to the information I have.
Three men have lost their jobs because the Parliamentary Secretary will not act.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: I have no say with regard to the termination of their employment or their reinstatement. However I have information on the matter and I shall give it to the Deputy. All three men have other employment and the board are satisfied they did not devote their fulltime efforts towards fisheries protection although they were told to do so. One man, in addition to being a cattle owner, drives the town's school children to school in his own minibus and the other two are farmers. Despite repeated warnings all were frequently absent at markets when they were required for duty. As the situation steadily worsened, in December, 1973 they were informed they must devote all their time to their duties. In March, 1974, they were warned in writing that failure to carry out instructions—namely, to be available for duty when required by the inspector—would lead to summary dismissal. In August, 1974, they were given a final warning. There were frequent complaints from anglers and others that the men were not present to protect the area and some members of the anglers' association expressed satisfaction and pleasure at the dismissal of the men.

Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that in the notification of their dismissal it was stated it was due to lack of work, that the board did not have sufficient work for them, that it had nothing to do with the service they had given?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: How could they do the work required of them by the board when they were at the mart selling their cattle?
They were appointed by the board years ago.

Would the Parliamentary Secretary be prepared to apply the same criteria to TDs? Does he think that if they are engaged in other work they might not be doing their work as public representatives in a successful way?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: What function has the Parliamentary Secretary with regard to TDs and their duties?
Why are two different kinds of criteria applied?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: The board of conservators applied the criteria and, in fairness to the board and from the information at my disposal, I must say I think their action was justified. If the allegations made by the board to the Department are incorrect I should be very pleased to hear from any Deputy on the matter.
Will the Parliamentary Secretary look into the following two questions: the inability of the men to work during “fish-ins” and the fact that they seized nets belonging to the board?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: That had nothing to do with their dismissal. It is an unfair reflection on the personnel of the board.

Speaker.hpid: Acting Chairman (Mr. M.E. Dockrell) Acting Chairman (Mr. M.E. Dockrell)
Speaker.P: I am calling Question No. 17.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Clogherhead Harbour.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries the plans he has to develop the harbour at Clogherhead, County Louth.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: I am awaiting a report from Louth County Council on investigations carried out by a firm of consulting engineers——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: Does the Parliamentary Secretary consider that £6 or £7 per week is a living wage——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: ——who were retained by the council to advise on works which are required at Clogherhead harbour.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: What does Deputy Barry Desmond or the Labour Party think is a living wage? Is it £6 or £7 per week——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: Until this information is received and examined in my Department, I am unable to say what developments would be justified at this harbour in the fishery interest.
I would ask the Parliamentary Secretary to repeat the reply because I have not been able to hear it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: I answered the question in accordance with the instruction of the Acting Chairman in a clear and distinct voice. If Members on the opposite side disobey the Chair, that is not my fault. However, I appreciate that Deputy Faulkner is an orderly Member and I will oblige him by repeating my answer. The answer is as follows:

I am awaiting a report from Louth County Council on investigations carried out by a firm of consulting engineers who were retained by the council to advise on works which are required at Clogherhead harbour. Until this information is received and examined in my Department, I am unable to say what development would be justified at this harbour in the fishery interest.

Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that the pier at Clogherhead is in a very dangerous condition? In view of the fact that fishermen and others in the area depend on it to obtain their livelihoods, would he deal with the matter urgently?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: My information is that the pier is in need of repair. If the Deputy will ask the Louth County Council to give us the information we require—they know all about it—I will do the best I can.

Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that it is not just a question of repairs? The pier is in a very dangerous condition and the fishermen are afraid that if a storm comes it will be destroyed. Further, would the Parliamentary Secretary agree that the work involved and the cost is far beyond the capacity of the county council? Will he take a personal interest in this matter to see that it is expedited?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: Perhaps the Deputy would use his offices with Louth County Council and ask them to send us the information we require. Then we could possibly proceed further.
Has the Parliamentary Secretary been in consultation recently with the county council in connection with the matter?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: The Louth County Council were requested to submit this information but for some reason or other it has not come to hand so far.
Will the Parliamentary Secretary state on what date the county council were requested to send the information?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: I do not know if I have that information here. In any event they were asked to send the details. There were negotiations in September, 1972, and August and October, 1973 but the actual date when the information was requested is not set out in my brief. However the Deputy can take it that the county council were requested some months ago to submit the information but for some reason it has not come to hand.

Surely the Parliamentary Secretary will agree that, if there were discussions in 1972 and 1973, the least he could do would be to get in touch with the county council in view of the very serious condition of the pier?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: It was explained to the council that the information sought was necessary before the Minister or the Parliamentary Secretary could accede to their request. The information sought has not been furnished by the council. That situation has obtained since August, 1973.
Perhaps the Parliamentary Secretary would send them a reminder?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: Yes, I agree with the Deputy's suggestion.
That is what I asked the Parliamentary Secretary to do—to get in touch with the county council on the matter.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Galway Fishermen's Facilities.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if his attention has been drawn to reports (details supplied) concerning support by BIM for Galway fishermen's claim for facilities; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: I have read the reports in question which refer to the efforts being made locally to obtain better facilities for fishermen from the Galway Harbour Commissioners. As these efforts are ongoing I do not propose to make a statement on the matter at this stage.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Kerry Test Borings.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if he will make arrangements whereby his Department will pay for test borings carried out by Tralee and Fenit Harbour Board, County Kerry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: I understand that the test borings in question were carried out by the Tralee and Fenit Pier and Harbour Commissioners in connection with the design of a major scheme of improvements to the commercial harbour facilities at Fenit, a grant for which would be a matter for the Minister for Transport and Power.

However, my Department are examining proposals for improvements at the Centre Quay section of the harbour which is used by the fishing fleet and for which trial borings would also need to be carried out. If the Office of Public Works advise my Department that the test borings already carried out provide the information required in relation to the Centre Quay section, I will consider the making of a contribution towards that part of the cost incurred in respect of the Centre Quay section.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
